executive_summary: Newspaper publishers have struggled to adapt a print-focused business model to a changing media landscape. Digital media outlets continue outperforming their print-focused counterparts but earn less revenue per customer in a market flooded with news websites. Newspaper publishing revenue has dropped at an annualized 3.2% over the past five years and is expected to total $30.8 billion in 2024 when revenue will dip an estimated 6.5% with a profit of 1.9%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation Highlights Print Newspapers' Struggles in the Digital Era
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Print newspaper sales have plummeted following the widespread shift to consuming digital news. Internet news sites, blogs, YouTube channels and cable news programs compete with print newspapers. Consumers prefer the lower cost (for some mediums), digestibility and mobility of receiving digital news.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Publishers Fight for Readers in a Fractured Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: An influx of digital news providers has ramped up competition among newspaper publishers. Websites range from prominent media companies, like Vox, to smaller niche news sites targeting specific readers. Traditional newspaper publishers also compete in the digital space, with online sales emerging to account for an increasing share of total industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Companies Find a Middle Ground by Using Paywalls and the Freemium Business Model
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Advertising dominates subscription and newspaper sales, especially as newspaper publishers transition to digital media. Print advertising expenditures have plummeted recently, weighing on this business segment for the average newspaper publisher.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry Enterprises Diversify Their Offerings Amid Shifting Conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Newspapers are diversifying their revenue streams beyond traditional advertising, exploring events, podcasts and other avenues in order to hedge against the loss of demand for traditional newspapers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Print-focused papers will try transitioning to non-profit status
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Traditional print newspaper publishers will consider transitioning to non-profits. Some publishers, like the Philadelphia Inquirer and The Guardian, have already taken this route. Newspapers that can find solid donation support can benefit from the tax status change and worry less about widening margins.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Digital newspaper publishers can leverage competitor platforms to engage the market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Newspaper publishers have leveraged competitor platforms, like social media, to engage more potential readers. Many newspapers maintain a Twitter or Facebook account to live report news and link articles to the company's website. Publishers must stay abreast of the latest and most popular online platforms to deliver content.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Skilled journalists from newspapers will continue serving as primary sources for breaking news
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cable and online news programs will cite discoveries by newspaper journalists from the New York Times or local papers. Many publishers benefit from the name recognition of journalists, as they can leverage their own online followings.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: REGULATORS WILL TURN TO SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS AND SEARCH ENGINES TO POLICE MISINFORMATION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Digital newspaper publishers have faced scrutiny for false reporting and lack of fact-checking standards. Traditional papers employ rigorous standards, while a minority of new competitors produce eye-catching headlines and articles that can mislead readers. Regulation surrounding digital news delivery has been an often discussed point of contention and has intensified along with the emergence of Artificial Intelligence in publishing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: NEWSPAPERS CONTINUE TO CHANGE THEIR BUSINESS MODEL TO REMAIN COMPETITIVE AND PROFITABLE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Newspapers are increasingly focusing on digital platforms, including online editions, mobile apps, and multimedia content. This shift corresponds with a continued change in consumer habits, away from daily expenditures on something like traditional newspapers.
The emergence of AI technologies has led to the advent of AI written articles. Should this method of content delivery grow in popularity, News Publishers could save on wage costs.

industry_definition: The Newspaper Publishing industry produces and distributes print newspapers. Companies that solely publish online news are excluded from this industry.
key_trends: Print newspapers have struggled to remain relevant and expand subscriber bases. The print market has undergone layoffs, closures, mergers and in some cases, transitioning to non-profit status.
Digital newspapers have outperformed their print-focused competitors but face competition from other news media, like.
Newspapers have leveraged mobile phones to engage younger and middle-aged readers better.
Digital papers have seen a rapid climb in digital subscribers' share of revenue, while print has lagged.
The First Amendment gives newspapers the right to publish criticisms of the government.
Newspapers conduct investigations into government practices and offer opinions on policies, providing an informal check on the government.
The Federal Communications Commission has relaxed laws prohibiting media consolidation.
Communication companies can own local radio, television, and newspaper news outlets in the 20 largest media markets.
Poor performance from print advertising coupled with low advertising prices for digital print have dragged the whole advertising segment down.
Older readers prefer print newspapers.
Younger readers overwhelmingly use digital news.
Middle-aged professionals use a mix of both to stay current on work-related topics and politics.
Local papers have merged to cover regional news and reach more subscribers.
This has created some consolidation among regional hub states.
National papers have acquired regional and local papers to expand subscription bases and create cost synergies.
The distribution of newspapers will skew to the right as prominent states like New York and California become top-heavy with papers.
Print newspapers have undergone widespread consolidation in response to fewer subscribers and diminishing advertising revenue.
Many local papers hope to be acquired by national papers or join forces with nearby papers to produce regional news.
Cable news remains a viral medium thanks to easily digestible reporting and live news updates. People don't always have the time to sift through newspapers and extract relevant information.

In February 2023, News Corporation announced a 5.0% reduction in its global staff after a dismal financial performance. The company's job cuts reflect staff reductions across newspaper publishers and signal many publishers' cost-cutting strategies.

The New York Times' acquisition of The Athletic in pursuit of its 10.0 million subscriber goal highlights widespread consolidation among prominent newspaper publishers. Companies have struggled to expand subscriber counts organically and hope to pick up newspaper readers by purchasing other companies' subscribers.
Print-focused newspapers have laid off staff and reduced publications to once a week to cut costs. Newspaper publishing remains labor intensive and papers purchase reports from freelance writers.
Digital newspapers attract new readers through freemium business models. Freemium gives readers access to a limited number of free articles before posting a paywall.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Many older readers have consistently read a print paper for decades. These loyal subscribers help keep print-focused and local newspaper publishers afloat. They additionally display brand loyalty and will typically procure products from the same industry enterprise.

The baby boomer generation makes up a massive percentage of the US population. Print subscribers will continue supporting newspaper publishers as this generation transitions into retirement. Other news mediums, namely cable news programs, have pulled older subscribers away from newspapers.

This age group has relatively high readership rates across both print and digital editions, though a majority of readership in this demographic occurs online. A small fraction of this age group reads print and digital newspapers equally. Many readers have a professional incentive to stay updated on the latest news coverage, especially regarding their line of work. Readers subscribe to financial, legal, political or scientific news sites.

Half of these readers subscribe to print editions, but this demographic has the highest online newspaper readership. Newspaper publishers recognize younger readers as a prized demographic for advertisers. The digital newspaper market has many competitors vying for younger readers. The fractured nature of the young readership keeps advertisement and subscription prices low. Younger readers frequent various websites and lack older newspaper readers' brand loyalty.

products_and_services.product_description: Advertising space remains an integral part of the newspaper publishing business model. Its worth has dropped as more competitors enter the digital newspaper market. Advertising share of revenue, not just its value, has shrunk in recent years.

Dedicated newspaper subscribers once formed the backbone of newspaper publishing. Many people still enjoy reading the physical paper, daily or the Sunday news. According to the American Press Institute, an estimated 82.0% of 50 to 64-year-olds read print news only.

Online subscriptions have become central to newspaper publishers in the digital market. Paywalls force readers to subscribe after a limited number of free articles, encouraging subscriptions after experiencing the value of the content. Dedicated news readers enjoy easy on-the-go access to digital news, leading many readers to subscribe willingly to their favorite online outlets. The vast volume of digital newspaper providers also splits the reader market, keeping subscription prices low.

Prominent newspapers like the New York Times manage printing plants. Smaller papers outsource printing to these companies, earning significant revenue for printers. This product segment has been particularly hindered by the absence of demand for print newspapers. Although as traditional papers continue to get creative as a means to circumvent revenue declines, this segment could grow.

tier_2_suppliers: Dye & Pigment Manufacturing in the US
Internet Service Providers in the US
Data Processing & Hosting Services in the US
tier_1_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Cable news remains a viral medium thanks to easily digestible reporting and live news updates.
Cable news remains a viral medium thanks to easily digestible reporting and live news updates. People don't always have the time to sift through newspapers and extract relevant information.

business_locations.location_description: Population determines the states with the most newspapers, including Texas, Florida, New York Illinois and California. These states have huge reader markets and substantial economic activity, ensuring plenty of content to report on.

Population determines the states with the most newspapers, including Texas, Florida, New York Illinois and California. These states have huge reader markets and substantial economic activity, ensuring plenty of content to report on.

Population determines the states with the most newspapers, including Texas, Florida, New York Illinois and California. These states have huge reader markets and substantial economic activity, ensuring plenty of content to report on.

Smaller hubs like Minnesota, North Carolina and Pennsylvania have smaller populations but regional prominence. Regionally important states post news from their neighbors and circulate in other states on a smaller scale than massive newspapers like the New York Times.

Smaller hubs like Minnesota, North Carolina and Pennsylvania have smaller populations but regional prominence. Regionally important states post news from their neighbors and circulate in other states on a smaller scale than massive newspapers like the New York Times.

Smaller hubs like Minnesota, North Carolina and Pennsylvania have smaller populations but regional prominence. Regionally important states post news from their neighbors and circulate in other states on a smaller scale than massive newspapers like the New York Times.
Mergers have led to top-heavy states in some regions, like Iowa having a relatively high number of newspapers despite its low population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The First Amendment gives newspapers the right to free speech and prevents the government from restricting free reporting. Newspaper publishers can publish content criticizing the government without facing legal repercussions. Newspapers can face charges for defamation and publishing damaging but untrue information.

The Copyright Act of 1976 provides a form of protection to authors of original works of authorship, including literary works. This protection goes for published and unpublished works. Section 106 of the US Copyright Act gives the owner, among other things, the exclusive right to reproduce the copyrighted work and to authorize others to do so.

In December 2007, the FCC voted to relax rules against businesses consolidating ownership in media outlets in a region. In certain circumstances, broadcasters in the nation's 20 largest media markets can purchase newspapers for business purposes. The revised rule establishes a presumption that the common ownership of a daily general circulation newspaper and a TV or radio broadcast station in the top 20 designated market areas (DMAs) would serve the public interest.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Newspapers need stories to publish, which usually come from staff writers. Some newspapers buy articles from freelance writers or hire temporary writers to supply consistent content. Finding good writers can make it difficult to break into the market.

basis_points.basis_description: National papers have acquired regional and local newspapers to expand subscriptions. The distribution of newspaper publishers across states is expected to shift toward the right as fewer states house more newspapers.

Print newspapers have undergone widespread consolidation in response to fewer subscribers and diminishing advertising revenue. Many local papers hope to be acquired by national papers or join forces with nearby papers to produce regional news.
Cable news remains a viral medium thanks to easily digestible reporting and live news updates. People don't always have the time to sift through newspapers and extract relevant information.

concentration_points.concentration_description: National newspapers have acquired regional papers to reach subscriber goals and create cost synergies. In February 2022, the New York Times reached its 10.0 million subscriber goal by acquiring The Athletic. Print and digital newspapers have struggled to create organic subscriber growth. Some local newspapers hope to reach deals with prominent national papers, while others work with their neighbors to gain regional prominence. Local papers have merged and shifted to region-specific weekly issues.
Many newspapers have transitioned to or entered the digital publishing market. Low barriers to entry have enabled an influx of news websites which keeps the digital market fractured.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many newspapers outsource reporting to freelance journalists. Printing plates, blocks, ink adhesives, newsprint, coated and supercalendered paper, and photographic film make up most material inputs, whether publishers perform printing operations in-house or outsource them to third parties. Many print publishers have reduced the printed page size for many publications as part of an effort to reduce costs.

Print newspapers underwent massive layoffs to cut costs, while digital papers ramp up hiring. Newspaper publishing requires journalists and salespeople to produce content and draw in advertisers. Newspapers don't rely heavily on capital; some maintain printing plants while others outsource printing. Print-focused and local newspapers have laid off journalists in response to lower revenue. Fewer papers mean less room for the abundance of print journalists that thrived just a few decades ago. Digital newspaper publishers have ramped up hiring to produce content but can pay writers less because of the high supply of journalists.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Newspapers need stories to publish, which usually come from staff writers
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Newspapers need stories to publish, which usually come from staff writers. Some newspapers buy articles from freelance writers or hire temporary writers to supply consistent content. Finding good writers can make it difficult to break into the market.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Paper holds back print-focused newspaper publishers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Society has reduced its reliance on paper products because of climate impact concerns and the high net benefits of going digital. People prefer to access news anytime, anywhere, without unfolding a colossal newspaper. The collapse of paper has accelerated the poor performance of newspapers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changes in advertising spends influence industry dynamics
volatility_points.volatility_description: Newspaper publishers were able to generate much of their revenue from advertising, but the proliferation of online and digital media has weakened print advertising spending. While many publishers can place ads on their sites, the advertising industry has shifted toward targeted ads on other platforms.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Advertising dominates newspaper publishing as prices creep down
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advertising space remains an integral part of the newspaper publishing business model. Its worth has dropped as more competitors enter the digital newspaper market. Advertising share of revenue, not just its value, has shrunk in recent years. Businesses used to purchase ad space in newspapers with prices varying by section. Today, most companies post ads on newspaper websites with pop-ups or ads in the margin. Using cookies to target advertisements based on user activity on other websites should make digital ads more valuable, but the massive supply of online ad space keeps prices low.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Older readers continue supporting print-focused papers
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Although advertising revenue has fallen overall it still accounts for over a third of newspaper publishing revenue in 2024. The industry's decline has been mirrored by this segment, marred by the plummet in print advertising expenditure. Dedicated newspaper subscribers once formed the backbone of newspaper publishing. Many people still enjoy reading the physical paper, daily or the Sunday news. According to the American Press Institute, an estimated 82.0% of 50 to 64-year-olds read print news only.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Online subscriptions have spiked thanks to easy access to news and freemium business models
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online subscriptions have become central to newspaper publishers in the digital market. Paywalls force readers to subscribe after a limited number of free articles, encouraging subscriptions after experiencing the value of the content. Dedicated news readers enjoy easy on-the-go access to digital news, leading many readers to subscribe willingly to their favorite online outlets. The vast volume of digital newspaper providers also splits the reader market, keeping subscription prices low.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Printing services keep large and small newspaper publishers in business
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Prominent newspapers like the New York Times manage printing plants. Smaller papers outsource printing to these companies, earning significant revenue for printers. This product segment has been particularly hindered by the absence of demand for print newspapers. Although as traditional papers continue to get creative as a means to circumvent revenue declines, this segment could grow.

FAQs.question: How have changes in individual consumer electronic use changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: The rise of smart devices has increased consumption of electronic media, hurting print publications. For some papers, increasing digital subscribership has somewhat offset reduced advertising expenditures.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: Although newspapers have focused on building subscription revenue, advertising continues to account for a substantial share of most newspapers' revenue.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit?
FAQs.answer: Locating in a major media market can give newspaper publishers easier access to talented reporters, editors and other creative professionals.

FAQs.question: Are you paying wages above or below what your competitors pay?
FAQs.answer: Newspapers have pursued a variety of strategies to reduce labor costs, including reliance on freelance workers. Many publications furlough large segments of their workforces to cut operating costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: As newspapers increasingly move online, they must adopt the latest tools available for providing digital content. Most newspaper publishers have developed websites, while major players have also developed mobile applications for their publications.

FAQs.question: How have software advances altered your company's operations?
FAQs.answer: Some new software has become available to automate certain content creation, particularly in video and data-heavy reporting topics. Advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence have altered how papers target consumers with advertisements.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as FCC policy changes?
FAQs.answer: Cross-ownership of newspapers and broadcasting has declined, limiting exposure to FCC regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Journalism groups, including public interest reporting nonprofits, can help papers with professional development and reporting resources.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is typically higher for major publishers, though some have operated with low profit as they invest heavily in acquisitions. Profitability has declined because of lower advertising revenue. Lower operating costs when publishing online, as opposed to in print, have helped to shield profit from declining too dramatically in the face of falling revenue.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your company's customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: A loyal reader base increases a newspaper's value to advertisers and represents a strong competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Can you differentiate yourself from competitors by providing niche content that is not mainstream or evergreen? What would this take to implement?
FAQs.answer: The ability to service niche markets can expand demand, attract advertisers and bolster revenue. Most publications lack the ability to regularly cover niche content and, therefore, the competitive environment for niche papers tends to be favorable.

FAQs.question: Do you employ experienced staff? Do you have guidelines for quoting reputable sources or do you take any source's word to unearth news quickly?
FAQs.answer: A high-quality product can attract readers and advertisers. To maintain their reputation, operators must follow journalistic guidelines for fact-checking and editorial guidelines to ensure the quality of their writing.

FAQs.question: Do you offer the same content online as in your print publication? How can you differentiate the two to get more readers?
FAQs.answer: Companies can improve and increase their offerings and reduce their costs by adopting new technologies, such as web publishing and printing technologies. Quick adoption of new technologies can provide market opportunities. Newspapers that offer online content that cannot be produced in print, such as video content and interactive dashboards, benefit from increased subscribership.

FAQs.question: How can you compete with publishers that provide content strictly on the internet? Have you increased your internet presence?
FAQs.answer: As digital-only publications rise in popularity, competition for newspaper publishing increases, threatening revenue growth. Newspapers that successfully compete in the online space must produce innovative digital content. Papers that produced particularly good, data-driven coverage of the pandemic have attracted a high volume of new readership.

FAQs.question: As corporate profit increases, what can you do to earn more advertising dollars? Do you have many clients currently?
FAQs.answer: Revenue typically trends in line with corporate profit, which if it increases, enables companies to spend more on print and online advertising. Online advertising has grown but doesn't earn huge revenue because of the vast supply of online ad space.

FAQs.question: How can you get consumers to use their increasing incomes to purchase a subscription to your publication? How can you differentiate yourself?
FAQs.answer: Growth in per capita disposable income typically translates into increased subscription numbers, which generates additional readership and, therefore, advertising revenue. Newspapers differentiate themselves based on the scope of their product offerings and the quality of their journalism.
